tn.text: These are stones with black and white lines that are used to make jewelry.
This refers to the beautiful and decorative designs or patterns formed by the stones.

the best quality and most valuable gold

willingly and without any doubt or hesitation

tn.ref: May you be praised, Yahweh, God of Israel our ancestor, forever and ever.
tn.text: AT: "May you be praised, Yahweh our father, God of Israel, forever and ever."
David continues his prayer of praise to Yahweh.

tn.ref: In your hand is power and might
tn.text: The words "power" and "might" mean the same thing and emphasize the greatness of Yahweh's power. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
David continues his prayer of praise to Yahweh.

tn.ref: But who am I, and who are my people, that we should be able to offer so willingly these things?
tn.text: David means that he and his people deserve no praise for giving anything to God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: we are strangers and travelers before you
tn.text: AT: "You know that we are insignificant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Our days on the earth are like a shadow
tn.text: Shadows appear and disappear quickly. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: in the uprightness of my heart
tn.text: "because I want to be honest and honorable in everything I do for you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: keep this forever in the thoughts of the minds of your people
tn.text: AT: "keep this in the thoughts and minds of your people forever"
See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]]
lay down facing the ground as a way of showing extreme respect
In order to honor Yahweh.

tn.ref: anointed him with Yahweh's authority to be ruler
tn.text: AT: "anointed him to rule over Israel on Yahweh's behalf"
AT: "their loyalty"

tn.ref: Yahweh greatly honored Solomon before all Israel and bestowed on him greater power
tn.text: These two phrases emphasize that Solomon received special favor from Yahweh, which made him Israel's greatest and most powerful king. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: written in the history of Samuel the prophet, in the history of Nathan the prophet, and in the history of Gad the prophet
tn.text: This is a work that no longer exists.

"the things that happened while David was king"
